ygData.subject: Re: Some free code
ygData.msgSnippet: ... Yes, I am writing this in Visual Basic.  But any kind of programmer should recognize what I am doing without having to have know Visual Basic: If-Then

--- In gladiator@y..., "Deathifier" <storey@t...> wrote:
> Visual Basic is what I recall DPH writing it in :)

Yes, I am writing this in Visual Basic.  But any kind of programmer 
should recognize what I am doing without having to have know Visual 
Basic: If-Then statements (there are some complex ones in there) and 
assignment statements.
 
> No comments are needed because it is really simple to understand 
what is going on - some conditions are checked on an object, and if 
met that object is modified a little.

You call changing a tree into a silver bar or a door while moving its 
coordinates a minor modification?  I am just showing an example of how 
 you could use code to make wide-scale changes on an existing map.
 
> There are more elegant ways of doing it though, they just require 
more time to create the foundation and need less time when defining 
'rules' -  the usual tradeoff.

There were more elegant ways, but I was looking for a simple solution. 
 Except for the 1st statement [all I did was change the team number 
for gold and silver], everything else pretty much relied on tracking 
coordinates of an object.  Even the variable names should be fairly 
obvious.

When I feel comfortable with deleting objects by code without 
screwing up the scenario file, I'll do a nice write-up about how to 
accomplish that.

When I finish that up, I'll do a nice write-up about one solution for 
adding objects by code (it'll be pretty be similiar to deleting 
objects by code).

The biggest thing I want to remind people is DON'T try to change the 
objects in the scenario file by code and save changes to the same file 
name.  I am saving the changes I am doing by code to a different file 
name in the event I screw things up [real easy to do when resetting 
object coordinates].

I am pretty convinced someone could set up a well documented program 
[in an interpreted language] designed just to modify objects in a 
scenario file on a wide scale.
